Not Enough Information. Getting frustrated. Failing legends everytime I start a new one because the quest goals aren't spelled out like in the board game. Legend 4 for example (something about fairies) *spoiler* if you don't send someone to the tree before time advances to B you lose... but nowhere is that stated in the quest description. In the board game this would be explicit. As it is I have to waste time guessing what's important and failing 2 or 3 times before figuring it out. Fix pls
Hoping another version is in the mix. This was a great app, based on an excellent game!

Started off well, then got annoying fast. Often you start a level with a very short number of turns to do an objective. Because the timer advances every time you fight there is often only one way to achieve that objective, so you're railroaded into a specific path. Then the next objective pops up and up find out that your archer is one space out of where it needs to be for you to achieve it in time. Restart mission. Same thing happens again on objective 3. Could have been great, isn't.

Overall a fun experience but a steep learning curve where game mechanics not really explained properly for a beginner to the world of Andor.

content: More of a puzzle game than a strategy game, I didn't much enjoy the learning curve or the game itself. Time progresses after every battle (not just after every day), so if you strategically kill everything in a single turn you'll run out of time and fail. It's more about planning what to skip over and ignore, and the minutiae of multi character movement to optimise move distance, escorting distance and gear ferrying. Due to turn order, not being able to trade when a hero is done for the day, and sitting still taking the same energy as moving one space ‚Äì this all just becomes tedious.
replyContent: Hi Justin, Thanks a lot for your detailed feedback! You've understood the most important aspect of Andor which is that it's not about killing every monster but that it's about planning how to manage your time. Deciding, that this concept is not something for you is very valid and we're thankful to you for sharing your opinion! Enjoy your day!

content: This is a really challenging but fun game. I highly recommend it if you like board games and carefully planning out your moves. It's essentially a board game puzzle with turn based combat. I call it a puzzle because most maps have very little flexibility in how to tackle the map. Quests all must be completed by a certain turn on the board, and there's rarely a lot of extra time to meet it. Most of the time you'll finish a quest at the last moment you can. Because of this, one mistake or bad dice roll can effectively end the map. Also, often they throw curveballs at you, like discovering you have to defeat a flying monster by turn 15, only to realize it's turn 14 and none of your heroes have a bow which is necessary to even fight a flying monster. This means you have to be overly prepared for everything, or just accept you'll spend 30 minutes on a map to lose at the last second to some surprise to have to do it all again. That's why it's essentially a puzzle. I'd give it 5 stars if there were a little more wiggle room in maps. But overall, it's well worth the money.

dropped to 4 stars considering without a save feature how stacked the game is against you can't count how many times a crucial fight goes with the enemy rolling doubles or how one mistake can cause complete failure due to time restraints (giant gor especially)
great implementation and graphics. looks there's a lot of playtime with all the adventures
replyContent: Thanks a lot Pablo! Enjoy playing further on!

content: Fantastic!

Combat is broken. Computer opponents roll a six over 75% of the time and/or doubles vastly higher than the actual statistics of rolling numbers like that. I shouldn't fail combat four times in a row because the computer opponents' rolls. Plus, like others have said, this game is basically a puzzle; once you figure out the solution to win a scenario (and there's literally only one) you just repeat it. There's zero variance. Had I known this game was like this I wouldn't have bought it.
replyContent: Hi Dave, we are sorry to read that you don't like the conception of the Andor app. In regards to the dice mechanisms I'd like to add that there is a 1 in 3 chance that an opponent is rolling a double with 3 dice. Especially at the beginning of the level, you should always fight with 2 heroes against a monster. Enjoy playing further on!

No choices, no action, if this is how the boardgame version is played, at least i didn't blow 10x as much on a physical copy. AVOID!!!

content: Full disclosure: I'm the composer and sound designer on this project, so I'm obviously biased. However, I've been an avid fan of the Andor board game series for many years and I can honestly say that the developers nailed the digital adaptation. It's true to the original in terms of its mechanics, it runs very smoothly on my Galaxy A3, and it provides lots of content at a really low (and up-front!) price. More often than not, mobile adaptations of established brands are lazy cash-grabs, but these guys have really gone the extra mile to make Andor fans happy.
replyContent: Thank you so much Mjeno!
